To answer this question, we need to understand the concept of lift in relation to bird flight. Lift is the force that allows birds to stay airborne. One of the factors that affects lift is the size of the bird. 

Sparrows are generally smaller birds compared to vultures. Smaller birds have lighter body weights, which means they require less lift to stay in the air. They also have smaller wingspans, which allows for more maneuverability, agility, and grace in flight. 

On the other hand, vultures are larger birds with bigger bodies and wingspans. Due to their larger size, they need more lift to stay airborne. Their flight may appear less graceful compared to sparrows because they rely on soaring instead of quick and agile movements.
